At 22:12 12/10/2004, you wrote:

> > Hi,
> >          I don't get the connection with back-propagation -- can you 
> explain?
> >
> >          Ian
>
>Sure...let me quote from one of your posts...
>
> >>There actually is a third, more sophisticated method for getting
> >>weight mutation parameters, which is to measure the success of
> >>mutations in various directions in the multidimensional space and
> >>actually construct a model of the most promising mutation trajectory
> >>based on the experience over past generations (as a multi-dimensional
> >>probability distribution).  That has recently popped up in ES as well,
> >>though the math behind it is not simple at all.
>
> >But that is a step away from the basis of an evolutionary search and
> >towards a gradient-based method.  Gradient-based methods are
> >well-established and the choice for many problems, but they have certain
> >weaknesses which evolutionary methods address... IMHO, that is.
>
>Basically, I was saying what you were saying...that this takes us one
>step closer to back-propagation / gradient-based methods.
>
>And that perhaps we might learn from both the successes and failures
>of that technique.  But that we would do well do do so conscientiously
>as opposed to re-inventing it in an effort to make improvements to our
>current approach.  Make sense?

Ah!  Yes I get you now.  This is a very good idea.

I think that only that one angle of the discussion directly relates to 
back-prop however.  The more-general point, about including parameters for 
mutation rate in the genome has less to do with it.  Although I suppose 
that when you have a mutability on every gene you kind-of have an unsigned 
"gradient" parameter.  Intuitively I feel that if the mutabilities are 
randomly evolving it is a more-robust search technique than if we were 
trying to calculate them from a single point on the fitness surface (or 
even a historical path across it).

I did see one study where what they did was:

1) maintain an evolving population (fixed topology)
2) before evaluating the fitness of each individual, train it with back-prop
         (they actually did it as a basic weight with a learned modifier 
added on, but that was just to help with analysis)

-what they were looking at was the Baldwin effect, which is where a 
property is initially learned, but over a longer-time gets transferred into 
the genome (because individuals who learn it faster are fitter, and 
eventually do not need to learn it at all...)

I can find the reference if you need it...

         Ian
